item.title: Northern English regions drive house price growth
item.description: Wales also records rapid rises as the UK sees property prices go up at the fastest rate for 17 years.

item.title: Nando's hopes to reopen fully from Saturday after supply shortage
item.description: The chain had to shut about 50 restaurants due to food shortages thought to include its signature peri-peri chicken.

item.title: Price rises cool amid clothes and shoe discounting
item.description: The UK inflation rate fell by more than expected to 2% in July, down from 2.5% the previous month.

item.title: Scottish public spending deficit doubles to £36bn
item.description: Spending on public services rose to almost £100bn as revenue fell due to the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Franco Manca owner planning big UK and overseas expansion
item.description: Restaurant group Fulham Shore plans to open up to 150 new outlets amid continued strong trading.

item.title: Trendy shoffices and pizza ovens raised lockdown fire risks
item.description: Insurer Zurich says residential outbuilding fires rose by 16% last year compared with 2019.

item.title: US left too quickly, says Afghanistan bank governor
item.description: Afghanistan central bank governor, Ajmal Ahmady, tells the BBC he thinks country's economic situation will deteriorate.

item.title: Covid: Australia's Qantas says all staff must be vaccinated
item.description: The announcement came as New South Wales reported its biggest daily rise in coronavirus infections.

item.title: Trials of shared banking hubs to be extended
item.description: The two trial projects allow different banks to operate from the same premises after branches closed.

item.title: Home Depot 'discriminated against BLM supporter'
item.description: The US DIY chain tried to stop a worker from raising issues of racial harassment with managers, a watchdog claims.

item.title: UK job vacancies at record high as wages pick up
item.description: Job vacancies hit 953,000 amid signs the country's labour market is rebounding "robustly".

item.title: Mastercard to end magnetic strip on cards
item.description: The company sets an expiry date of 2033 for the decades-old technology.

item.title: BHP: Mining giant to leave London's FTSE 100 for Sydney
item.description: The company, which has been part of the blue chip index for 20 years, is scrapping its dual listing.

item.title: Afghan bank governor flees saying country left in chaos
item.description: Afghanistan's central banker Ajmal Ahmady says he tried to maintain calm before fleeing crowds and gunshots.

item.title: Former ITV boss Adam Crozier appointed new chairman of BT
item.description: Adam Crozier, who has previously headed the TV company and the FA, will join the telecoms giant this year.

item.title: No need to swap data for drinks, says privacy body
item.description: Some pub ordering apps ask too many questions, but you can refuse, says the information watchdog.

item.title: Love and money: 'I borrowed from a friend, it went wrong'
item.description: After sleeping on the night bus with her daughter, Jo was forced to borrow money.

item.title: Covid testing is rip-off, says former regulator
item.description: Lord Tyrie, ex-boss of the competition watchdog, says it was slow to react to complaints about providers.

item.title: What next for Afghanistan's economy?
item.description: Now that the Taliban are back in control of the country, can its financial system function?

item.title: Bezos sues Nasa over its deal with Elon Musk's SpaceX
item.description: Mr Bezos's Blue Origin says it was unfairly treated after being excluded from lunar landing contract.

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: Airlines reroute flights out of Afghan airspace
item.description: Virgin Atlantic made its last journey over the region on Sunday while Emirates has suspended flights.

item.title: 'New York vaccine mandate could destroy my restaurant'
item.description: City residents need to be jabbed to use restaurants, gyms and theatres - and businesses are worried.

item.title: Pingdemic: 'We got close to complete shutdown'
item.description: Businesses say self-isolation rule changes will have a "massive impact" on reducing staff shortages.

item.title: UK defence giant Ultra agrees to £2.6bn Cobham takeover
item.description: The deal to buy the major supplier to the Royal Navy is being monitored by the UK government.

item.title: Parcel delivery texts now the most common con-trick
item.description: Text messages asking for a fee to deliver a package are responsible for most "smishing" fraud.

item.title: New powers sought to stop illegal ticket resales
item.description: The UK's competition watchdog is calling for stronger laws to act quickly against touts.

item.title: How do couples handle awkward chats about money?
item.description: From squabbles and lies to what they'd do if they won the lottery, we pose the awkward questions.

item.title: Afghanistan: Facebook continues ban of Taliban-related content
item.description: Technology firms face challenges on how to handle content created by the group and its supporters.

item.title: Japan's economy bounced back ahead of the Olympics, data shows
item.description: Analysts have warned recovery will be modest this quarter after a state of emergency was re-imposed.

item.title: Never mind going electric, where will we park?
item.description: UK roads are already jam-packed and that looks set to get worse as more people snap up EVs.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: How can new technology protect outdoor workers?

item.title: How we can all get more high-quality sleep
item.description: The pandemic has led to a sharp increase in insomnia, but some firms are now helping their staff.

item.title: CEO Secrets: Foot Locker boss shares his advice
item.description: Richard Johnson, CEO of Foot Locker, reflects on the lessons of the pandemic for business leaders.

item.title: Sharing apps are booming but will the kindness continue?
item.description: The pandemic sparked a surge in activity for sharing apps like Olio but has the trend run its course?

item.title: Can technology help authors write a book?
item.description: Writing a novel is notoriously difficult, but technology may give the writer a helping hand.

item.title: The activist entrepreneurs running zero-waste shops
item.description: Environmentally conscious entrepreneurs explain the movement towards zero-waste lifestyles.

item.title: Why artificial intelligence is being used to write adverts
